reviews.review_text: Pros: Interesting storyline.  Quite easy to get use to the shooting/gameplay mechanism.  Graphics and the sound/fx   Cons: I dont see one yet.  It's pretty good for a Singleplayer campaign. Quite challenging at certain points but manageable. Recommended!

If you have watched any number of genuine helmet cam war videos, you will appreciate the highly realistic portrayal of tactics. This is not a corridor shooter. It is a roleplaying game best enjoyed when you immerse yourself in your role and play it out like the real soldiers.  The gameplay settings are pleasantly variable - sniping, sneaking, assault, and vehicle levels with the respective operator groups. This includes the actual equipment each of them uses and their expectable sound and power of effect. This is a chiseled out and fact-checked shooter I would definitely recommend any day.

SINGLE-PLAYER REVIEW  From the serie that 'started it all', that led the way for cinematic FPS games, I expected more than this. I played the whole MoH serie since the ps1 games, so I know how it was born and grew. The story is the usual, recycled, already seen soup, which is quite boring and you can skip with no regrets. The problem is that you can only skip movies and not cutsecenes, so if you want to replay the game, you'll have to watch them again and again, and they last for about 50% of the level time.  The real problem is the gameplay, though. Being used to games that tells you everything you need to push in order to even move, so much that it gets annoying, I was surprised that this game tells you nothing at all. Well, it tells you what to push to move and jump, the basics that everyone already knows, but not how to use the special equipment you're supposed to use in the 'mini-games'. Ok, there's no mini-games here, but there's special sequences where you need to use a special binocular to mark targets for bombing, a sequence where you use the weaponry of an helicopter, and some sniper sequences. Well, on the first 2 modes you have more than 1 firing mode but the game doesn't tell you that, and you end up wondering why certain targets don't blow up, or why the game keeps telling you to do something that you're already doing. The actual FPS mode is sub-par, too. You can't choose what weapons you start the mission with, and you can only collect enemy weapons (not ammo to refill your one, unless it's the same model) or ask your friends for ammo, if they use the same one as yours. The action has so many little breaks because you either have to climb a 1.5 meters step with the help of a teammate, something exploded near you and you take a whole 15 seconds to get on your feet again, a whole lot of enemies arrived at a near position (so it's better to just look at them instead of firing, right?), the teammates has something to tell you, and so on. It's frustrating. The fact that the game is also an on-rail shooter, with no space for exploration and only one way from point a to point b, makes the SP experience feel so restricting and unsatisfying, that the fact that it only last 3 hours won't bother you so much at the end. Yes, you've read it right, 3 hours. That is about how much it took me to complete this game. It wasn't even so much fun for those 3 hours. The game plays the compassion card for all the soldiers that actually went into those places, risking their life for our freedom. Well I'm sorry, but there's already movies for that and when I buy a game I want a game, not a barely interactive movie. I'm sorry for those people and I really appreciate their work, and I think it's not honest to use their sacrifice to make bad games.  The only thing that barely saves this game from being a complete disaster are the graphics. I get a solid 60fps in full-hd and everything at max, with vsync on, but it only looks good during daylight missions (like with most games anyway), and even there there's part of the graphics that is too blocky and/or has bad textures, but it's overall pretty good looking. The audio is a mess, though. The sound can barely be heard and you have to increase the volume at almost maximum in your audio equipment.  Oh yeah, there's an additional game mode in SP, where you fight your way in a selected level for leaderboard score. Such fun. If only they added coop, that could have marginally saved this terrible game, but as it is, it's the usual EA game: just bad.
Very copy paste action shooter game. Painfully obvious. Story is not good. Wow 3/10

A triumph of game design! A tour-de-force in everything that makes EA the creativity powerhouse it is today! An immaculate masterpiece that will surely be enjoyed for generations to come.  I would bet that someone at EA wouldn't even believe that if they read it. They know what kind of company they are, and they know what kind of game they make. This game had no surpises, and I only played it to remove it from my 'unplayed games' list. Ok, here's the review.  EA's Least Shiatty Game since Medal of Honor: Allied Assault (actually, MOHAA was good. I'll give them that)  'Let's relentlessly kill A-rabs for 2 hours!' Basically, it's pretty graphics and not much else. The gameplay is meh.... You're forced along a very strict path with glass walls if you try to stray even slightly. There's one great scene where you approach a small village in an Apache (that you don't control, you just hold down m1+m2 and it shoots stuff), and they just say 'Everyone is hostile here. Kill EVERYTHING' and you destroy every building in a village, undoubtedly killing children and civilians. There are lots of short easy gun battles between scripted events. The SEALs will tell you stuff like 'be really really quiet here, we want to be sealthy'. So you can, if you want, sneak along and kill nobody, or you can fire a few shots into the air, and your team will kill everyone for you. The controls are also screwed up too. For example, there was a mission where you're in a helicopter and all of a sudden you need hellfire missiles to take out a mortar, and the button for hellfire missiles isn't left click, right click, melee, grenade, or any of those keys, even though the last two of those are pointless in a helicopter. Instead, you have to hold down 4 for 2 seconds, even though there's nothing that binds 4 to any action. Really intuitive, right?  1.5/5

I first played this game and hated it I must say. But then I decided to reinstall it and give it a shot, mainly because I was a huge fan of the old Medal of Honor games and because I felt like I was being mean to the game itself. What can I say? It is definitely not the best FPS I ever played but still, I found it is a good one, decent story, decent setting and overall in my honest opinion, a great soundtrack. The graphics look kinda nice for a game of 2010, specially coming from DICE. But the only thing that I kinda found weird was the shooting, the mouse moved really weird and the guns themselves were okayish, some of them had a nice and decent kick to them when you fired but I got the feeling that firing from the hip worked every single time, specially when spraying. That said, I'd say that you should probably give it a try if you're a fan of the old Medal of Honor games or if you're just bored someday.

In honor to the franchise which I thought was decent, I highly recommend MOH. The gameplay feels authentic and real. Your in real world locations and fighting alondside actual US military. The games unique gameplay in authenticity is what I like most. Yes it is a far cry from COD and multiplayer is not great, but the short single player campaign is worth a run.  The graphics are excellent for 2010 and the geography is realistic. It is a linear game though so not much exploring. The sound design is impressive, the guns and firefights sound very realistic. The radio chatter is all authentic military, be it somewhat pervassive language. You feel like part of the team. The ending was a nice touch, I salute the men and women who have to encounter these real world scenarios and I think the game gives you a sense of what it is all about.  There will be no more MOH (EA pulled the plug on franchise) and maybe players did not get that this was not trying to be COD, thats what BF3 is for or maybe they felt it was very short which it is. Bottom line is for a game of this quality and if on sale I would recommend picking it up. Cheers to MOH, always liked this games style even if it was not that popular.  ✓Recommended

I got this from a Humble Bundle, and I always liked the games they selected for being included in a bundle. It's the first Medal of Honor I played, and I must say it has lessened my respect for all parties involved, including Humble for giving this more attention than it deserves. This game doesn't have any redeeming qualities I could come up with. Gameplay is bad, execution is bad, pacing is bad, sound design is bad, everything else is bad. It's just junk, and it reminded me why I was reluctant to play war shooters in the first place. You can feel that they tried pretty hard to clone Call of Duty (I mean, just look at the title, duh). Even the description on Steam is involuntarily hilarious. '...a relatively unknown entity of handpicked warriors'? Who writes stuff like that with a straight face? It's a persiflage of its own subject matter. The realistic enactment of war simply shouldn't be treated in a way like this, it's inadvertently offensive and cheap. Although I feel bad for giving a bad review for a game I paid almost zero $ for, I'm still desperate to warn everyone about giving this game a chance. If you have to, take Call of Duty on for another playthrough, it's still better after the third time than this is during any given 30 minutes of its awful campaign. Please note that I never played any Medal of Honor multiplayer, it may well be its singular redeeming quality, since there must be a reason for it to exist at all. So there. Hope you didn't buy this at anything more than a dollar.

I'm having some fun playing this but other times I just want to get to the end. The characters are boring. Seems like everybody is a hardened white commando from about the same background and with the same attitude and feelings about everything except for one black commander who might as well be white and one white general or CIA guy or something who should be a lot better actor. The sound is bad. There's lots of err... homoerotic commando whispering in your ear as you stealthily follow the one and only path to 'penetrate' your next objective like Dorothy for instance. I like it but the whispering voice sounds the same way no matter if that commando is in front of you, behind you or fifty feet in front of you. And your name keeps changing as you switch identities for no apparant reason. The cities aren't much bigger than farms. The guy directing you often tells me to do things but I have trouble following his instructions. It helps to press H so that your objective lights up for a little while. Its not really that important because there aren't any different ways to go but it took me some time to figure that out.   Quite a few times I've been unable to progress and been forced to restart a mission. I'm often annoyed with the game choosing my weapon. Can't I be allowed to make any decisions? I've played other games that allow me to pick weapons and choose paths and my name. That's how I prefer it. This game doesn't allow a lot of freedom in allowing you to pick what you'll do next or how you'll do it and its very repetitious. There's one mission where you are taking cover in some crumbling mud shack and the enemy streams in forever down the hills around you. It just gets tiring picking them off. Hard to believe they would waste that many guys on that pathetic tactic but I suppose it could happen.   What's going on with that Barret sniper rifle view? Its like they mounted a camera on the back of a camel walking on rocky terrain in high winds.  The graphics are good and there's a lot of action. Its not as good as taking a walk but its better than raking leaves. This game is not sleep inducing. It'll tire you out but it will also make you feel restless and and angry. If you need to fall asleep I recomend Eurotruck simulator.

SP: The story is pretty powerful, as it's loosely based on the real events of the Battle of Roberts Ridge. It's a gripping story and the cutscenes do it justice. The gameplay however is very monotonuous. The Taliban fighters just seem to come at you like a wave of zombies. When they shoot from cover, it's like your're playing one of those flash games where the enemies pop up at exactly the same place in a periodic manner. This makes the enemies feel very unreal and almost laughable. You also don't have any room to diverge from the beaten track, it's a completely linear shooter like CoD.  MP: The unlock system just simply and plainly sucks. The stock weapons are not much fun to use and getting some interesting unlocks takes ages. Aiming feels off compared to other first-person shooters, they probably put some sort of mouse acceleration in the game that you can't turn off. The maps and game modes get old really quickly too. It feels like they didn't put much thought in to the MP portion of this game.  Conclusion: only get this game in a sale to get dragged away by the story, but you probably won't play it much afterwards.

This game wasn't bad, but there isn't enough content to warrant spending any more than about $5. Still, there is some fun to be had; the sliding and stabbing mechanics can make you feel pretty bad**s and headshots reward you with a satisfying splat. The shooting mechanics are fine and the graphics are pretty good (some scenes of the mountains are actually breathtaking) but that's where the good ends really.The campaign is kind of cool because it feels a bit like you're playing the movie 'Lone Survivor' but it's far too short - like mayyybbe five hours. The characters and story are bland and I couldn't make myself care about any of it which is unfortunate given that this game is supposed to represent a real, ongoing conflict that involves many real people. The AI is terrible and each gunfight devolves into waiting for each individual head to pop out from behind cover. The game is glitchy and has little direction as to which rock you have to hide behind to activate the next scripted event. At one point, I got into a death loop beacause I was killed by a truck rolling into my cover and blowing up only to be spawned directly in front of that very same truck just before it exploded again. I almost exited the game right then but I eventually got out of the loop and found that if you manage to get yourself back to where the enemies spawn, they will completely ignore you because you are not where the game expects you to be. It's stuff like this that really ruins what could have been a cool concept for the Medal of Honor reboot. I got this game in a humble bundle so I'm not too worried about value, but I can't really recommend this game unless you can grab it for $5 or less.

I was going to write a long, over informative review explaining why this game is so underrated and why it’s worth your time, but I realized about 3 paragraphs into what would have been a small book that it will just fall on deaf ears.   Simply put , this game is good, worth your time, has excellent controls, and if you aren’t a CoD fanboy, you’ll probably find it can really draw you in if you let it.  Its plot is loosely based on real events, and it aims for a more realistic approach to modern shooters. It aims to show honor and respect to out war fighters and give us something of a more realistic glimpse into what they live and face than its counterparts attempt too. It’s true a lot of what’s in this game is more of the same, but the same can be said about the competition. You have to understand it’s a war game, about a war. It’s always going to be more of the same.  What really drew me into this game were all the suspenseful moments and the amazing controls. I get that its short and pretty linear, but so is  every  other modern shooter,  period . It’s called story mode, not free mode, so of course it’s going to be linear. And like every other shooters story mode it follows a script.  The only thing that really turned me off to this game was the ending. I thoroughly enjoyed the events up until the very end  when Linkin Park starts playing and all seriousness of the tragic events that just transpired are gone.

I didn't think I was going to like this game after reading some of the reviews. The single player campaign was surprisingly good. The only blemish is the enemy spawning. There are a few sections where the enemies will spawn indefinitely unless you advance your position. It ruins the willing suspension of disbelief for those sections of the game, although it should be noted that the enemy spawning didn't make the game unfair. It's just that enemy respawning indefinitely is an outdated convention. I would have given the single player campaign a 9/10 if not for that single blemish. Still, I had a lot of fun playing the game. The weapons were some of the best I've ever used in a FPS war game and the action was always engaging. The story was typical, but how many of us play FPS's for their story? The campaign was short; six hours tops, but it was never boring. The graphics were excellent and the explosion effects were second to none. I don't know why this game was reviewed so poorly. I didn't play in multiplayer, so consider this review only if you are interested in the single player campaign. 8.5/10

This game is a decent game. It has pretty grafix and it runs decently. It's worth picking it up on a sale to experience the mediocre but enjoyable story. This is the perfect Call of Duty clone. It wants to be Modern Warfare so bad it's not even funny. Down to the smallest detail. If I have one complaint about the Singleplayer is that it's sensitivity option is PURE ♥♥♥♥♥! It doesn't go low enough. I've lowered the DPI on my mouse and it still goes WAY faster than I would like to. It's such a basic option, yet they didn't fiddle enough with it so it makes the game kinda unplayable for me, I had to pull every trick in the hat, lower Windows sensitivity and so on so forth, to make it playable. Every game's sensitivity option should go from 0 to 100. 0 being DEAD STOP, not moving at all, 100 being crazy fast. Not this game. This game is special.... This is even more curios because the MULTIPLAYER's sensitivity option is very good. It does what it's supposed to do, it goes as low as you want it to, until it stops moving completely. Weird. So this nice segway brings us to multiplayer. If you're buying it for the MP, DON'T. Get the latest COD, it'll be the same. At the time of writing there are only about 100 players playing the MP at any given time! Only a couple of the 4-5 MP modes are played, and those are not the best kind of modes. Not to mention that those 100 players, given their dedication, are MAX level and have every little ♥♥♥♥ unlocked, so they're like 5 times more powerful than you, due to the better upgrades they have. If you want a compelling MP experience similar to this go play COD, or try your luck with Medal Of Honor Warfighter, but even with Warfighter I don't think the MP community is what it was at launch, not that this game even EVER had a decent MP community, not even at launch. So bottom line is, buy this game at a sale to experience the decent Singleplayer campaign. That is all.

I started playing this game not expecting much. Then the only reason I continued playing it was just because I could laugh at it. And then I realized that trying to laugh at it was just making me slowly die inside. So having finally uninstalled it, here are some of the main things that I find completely ridiculous in this game:     Apparently your character's arms are made of wet spaghetti noodles, because while your squadmates have no trouble lifting their arms above their head and hauling themselves onto a ledge, you have to get one of them to boost you up by running over and pressing a button.    The game shatters all attempts at being taken seriously when it chooses to call these helping hands 'buddy boosts'.    The plot is dull, the voice acting lifeless (and bad in places), and expects you to care about a bunch of guys whose 'names' go from the semi-reasonable (Voodoo) to the hilariously ridiculous (Mother). Ex: Mother: Okay, we have to go do the thing and then the thing and the stuff. Voodoo: Thanks, Mom. Me: YOU ACTUALLY WANT ME TO THINK THIS IS ALL GRITTY AND SERIOUS?!?!    The game restricts you at every turn. There was a point where I tried to enter a house with a wide open door. I could see inside! And yet the doorway was just an invisible wall. Note that this is not always the case, but still...If you can't enter somewhere, just close the door! On another occasion, I was walking along a cliff and decided to try and jump off - you know, for science. NOPE. Invisible wall. No fence or wall that would be a reasonable blockade - nothing that justified me not being able to do this. Just the developers saying, 'We don't want you to go over there, but we're too lazy to actually show you that.'    BUDDY BOOSTS.    At one point, your character gets blood splattered on his face, and the camera shows blood splats. Keep in mind that your character is not wearing goggles, thereby implying he has blood on his eyes. Then your squadmate comes over and magically wipes the blood away! Thanks for molesting my eyeballs, buddy.    The pistol is hilariously overpowered. I went through entire sections of the game just going crazy with it. It has enough range that you can snipe people from decently far away, it shoots quite fast, and it has infinite ammo (unlike your other weapons).    FREAKING BUDDY BOOSTS.    When the game does give you a bit of freedom, it's ridiculous how quickly it can fall apart. There was a part where I ran ahead of my squad, shot everyone in the area while my team was monologuing, and then ran to the back of the area while the next scene triggered. After an air strike came through, I pulled out a grenade and counted it off. After a couple of seconds, I hurled it into a seemingly empty alcove, where a moment later, about five enemy fighters spawned and were immediately blown up.    Your squadmates can and often will play the game for you. There were times were I ran into an area, fired off some shots to get the enemy's attention, and then crouched behind a wall while my squad took out everyone. Word of advice, devs: Making the player feel completely irrelevant to a game's outcome does not make them want to keep playing.    THEY ACTUALLY THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A GOOD IDEA TO CALL THEM BUDDY BOOSTS WHO THE HELL WAS IN CHARGE OF THAT?!?!?!?!   In addition, the plot is dull, the graphics aren't anything special (hooray...gray...), the sound is unremarkable (my friend commented that a hail of gunfire just sounded like hail), and the gameplay is, in many cases, entirely optional. Just...go play a shooter that actually seems to care about the player.  TLDR: THIS GAME SUCKS BECAUSE BUDDY BOOSTS.

Medal of Honor is an ordinary average shooter, nothing more. The solo campaign can not compete with a CoD Modern Warfare, for example. The lack of a good story is the reason why there is no real suspense or excitement. You get thrown in the middle of the action and don't know exactly what you are doing there and why. The weaponfeel is not bad, but CoD is better, still. The graphics are mostly very pretty, but some levels look so terrible you can hardly believe it's the Frostbite Engine being used - seen mostly at the beginning of the campaign and in night missions. After an incredibly boring first 30-60 minutes, the solo campaign becomes significantly better and more varied - until all of a sudden you're done (and you don't know why, really unexpected) and the game ends with the credits on screen. Really disappointing, after the initial trailers had been quite promising.
